Monsieur le Ministre, I have the honour to direct the attention of Your Excellency to the increasingly frequent practice of interference by Iranian naval vessels with Koweiti and other Arab dhows, and to refer in particular to two recent cases of such interference which have been brought to the notice of His Majesty^ Government. 2. His Majesty*s Government are informed s (1) that on the 11th March one dhow was stopped at a point 30 miles North West of the island of Kh/arg by an Iranian naval ve^el which caused serious damage in coming alongside. It appears that the boarding party failed to board the dhow owing to heavy seas; (2) that on the 18th March two dhows were stopped by an Iranian naval vessel 18 miles from the nearest point of the Iranian shore in the vicinity of Tahirl. Both these dhows were boarded and searched. A few articles were stolen and in each case a sum of $s 1,000 was demanded, although the dhows were eventually released upon payment of a small levy. 3. I am to point out to Your Excellency that the dhows concerned in these incidents, which were returning to Koweit from India, were flying the flag of Koweit and were stationed well outside Iranian territorial waters when they were intercepted. mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence concerning a number of incidents in which vessels of the Persian Government detained or interfered with Arab vessels in the Gulf. The correspondence discusses the details of these incidents (most of which relate to Bahraini vessels) and also contains broader discussions about how Britain should react to them.On folios 53-55, the file contains the protocol agreed on in the event of a commanding officer of a British ship observing an Iranian warship or customs vessel interfering with a protected Arab vessel.The file also contains an original account (in Arabic and English) of a Bahraini captain named Ali bin Abdullah Al Naaimi written after he and his vessel had been detained by the Persian authorities in 1941 (f 61).
